user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_NewNode:
```c
UtListNode_t *UtList_NewNode(void *Data, uint32 DataSize)
{
    union NodeAllocator
    {
        UtListNode_t Node;
        double       AlignDbl;
        void *       AlignPtr;
        long         AlignLong;
    } * AllocNode;

    AllocNode = malloc(sizeof(union NodeAllocator) + DataSize);
    memset(AllocNode, 0, sizeof(union NodeAllocator));
    AllocNode->Node.Data     = &AllocNode[1];
    AllocNode->Node.DataSize = DataSize;
    memcpy(AllocNode->Node.Data, Data, DataSize);

    AllocNode->Node.Next = &AllocNode->Node;
    AllocNode->Node.Prev = &AllocNode->Node;

    return &AllocNode->Node;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_NewNode:
typedef struct UtListNodeTag
{
    struct UtListNodeTag *Next;
    struct UtListNodeTag *Prev;
    void *                Data;
    uint32                DataSize;
    uint32                Tag;
} UtListNode_t
...
typedef uint32_t  uint32
...
void UtList_Add(UtListHead_t *ListHead, void *Data, uint32 DataSize, uint32 Tag)
{
    UtListNode_t *TagHead;
    UtListNode_t *NewNode;

    TagHead = UtList_GetHead(ListHead, Tag);
    if (TagHead != NULL)
    {
        NewNode      = UtList_NewNode(Data, DataSize);
        NewNode->Tag = Tag;
        UtList_Insert_Before(TagHead, NewNode);
    }
}
...
UtListNode_t *UtList_GetHead(UtListHead_t *ListHead, uint32 Tag)
{
    if (Tag >= ListHead->NumberOfTags)
    {
        return NULL;
    }
    return &ListHead->Tags[Tag];
}
...
void UtList_Insert_Before(UtListNode_t *ExistingNode, UtListNode_t *NewNode)
{
    NewNode->Next       = ExistingNode;
    NewNode->Prev       = ExistingNode->Prev;
    NewNode->Prev->Next = NewNode;
    NewNode->Next->Prev = NewNode;
}
...
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of the standard library function memcmp in the provided code. The listed fragments perform allocation, zeroing, raw memory copy (memcpy), and string copy (strncpy), but none perform comparisons with memcmp or otherwise compare null-terminated strings using memcmp:

- UtList_NewNode: uses malloc, memset, memcpy to copy raw Data by DataSize — no memcmp and the copy is size-based (not a null-terminated string comparison).
- UtList_Add / UtList_GetHead / UtList_Insert_Before: simple control and pointer operations; no memcmp calls.
- UtTest_AddCommon: uses strncpy to copy TestName (a string) into a fixed buffer — this is not memcmp.

Because Rule 21.14 specifically prohibits using memcmp to compare null-terminated strings and no memcmp invocations appear in the provided code, there are no suspicious fragments to report for investigation.
